displayed_text: Patient: Okay. Doctor: Um, and then, we will set up when you need to come back, but I want you to take a look at these two, read them. We’ll know the AR-V7, hopefully within a week’s time. If that’s positive, then that would be this one. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And if it’s negative, it could be that one. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Or, if it was positive, you could still do that one. Um. Patient: Okay. Doctor: That one doesn’t care. Patient: Right. If everything looks good, I’d like to come back on the nineteenth. Doctor: Right. So, if we communicate by MyChart or I_ and I will communicate with you about stopping the drugs, if you decide, but I want you to take a look at it Patient: Okay. Doctor: More, more.

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the last 2 years (1 year but less: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the last 2 years (1 year but less than 2 years ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.None: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::None

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.disagree: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::disagree

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.agree: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::agree

You completely trust doctors' decisions.agree: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::agree

A doctor would never mislead you about a.disagree: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::disagree

All in all, you trust doctors completely.neutral: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::neutral

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.agree: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::agree

People of my ethnic group are treated th.agree: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::agree

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.agree: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::agree

Which of the following best describe you.Employed: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Employed
Which of the following best describe you.Student: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Student

What is the highest grade or level of s.College graduate: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::College graduate

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.Yes, Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::Yes, Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.Some other race: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::Some other race

displayed_text: Patient: …and then we’re gonna do some evaluations, we’re gonna make some decisions and we’ll… Doctor: Okay. Patient: …we’ll formalize a plan and we’ll go from there. Doctor: Yes. And then you go on vacation, when you come back we’ll have more data. Patient: Sure. Doctor: And then we have multitude of options including standard pills… Patient: Mhmm. Doctor: …standard chemo, and/or clinical studies of which there are several. Doctor: Okay. Patient: Good. Doctor: So I’m gonna have M____ come in… Patient: Mhmm.

Patient: Right. Doctor: And it hardly ever goes to you know oh look it’s all gone. Maybe you get one or two things Patient: Yeah. Doctor: and you just don’t see it, but your lymph nodes are substantially smaller. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Substantially, so this sucker’s totally working because you know the drop of your PSA not including today, but in the past have all been down. Family Member: Right. Patient: Yes. Doctor: So I’m fine with it. We fuss over big joints, hips, legs… Patient: Okay. Doctor: Shoulders because they can crack. Family Member: We were thinking it was right and not left.

Patient: So did you like Budapest? Doctor: Yes, it was interesting. I mean I had limited time, but it was… Patient: Yeah we did too. Doctor: I don’t think I would have ever thought of Budapest to visit if it weren’t for this meeting where I to be there. Patient: Yeah yeah right. Well we had been there. Doctor: It’s an incredible city. Oh my gosh! Like I never knew about, never thought about. Patient: And we never had enough time either. Doctor: Really? Even you went on your cruise right? Family Member: We were supposed to be there two days but then we had some problems with the boat so we had – they limited it to one day. They had to cut out some things. Doctor: And you thought that wasn’t… Patient: No. Family Member: No.

Family Member: No, but I remember you mentioned that once before. Okay. Doctor: So that’s actually, keep that in mind. Family Member: Okay, okay. And what hormone is he getting that decreases the… Doctor: It’s called Lupron or LHRH. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: Luteinizing hormone-releasing hormone LHRH. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: Or commonly known as Lupron is the brand name. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: There’s other brands too, but that’s the brand we use. Family Member: Okay. Okay. And anything else? I’m asking all the questions. (Laughs) Patient: No. I just….

Family Member: And, there’s something else? Patient: Is this in my chart? Doctor: Yes. Patient: Okay. Doctor: I just printed it out. Family Member: Uh, yeah. Doctor: It’s in the, um – Family Member: We can have that. Patient: Test results? Doctor: Well, for me, it’s in a tab called “media.” I don’t know what you have access to. Family Member: But it’s the only thing that came up in, in that genetic testing. Doctor: Right. So they, they look at, they look at about thirty genes that are key genes for cancer.

Patient: Oh no. Doctor: There’s a vacuum devise that we can use Patient: Um hmm. Doctor: and ultimately there’s a penile prosthesis. Patient: Um hmm. Doctor: That we can give and we have a person here now who specializes in sexual function. Patient: Um hmm. Doctor: And in fact maybe I’ll have him see you. Patient: I do want a relationship with someone Doctor: Okay. Patient: with people you know because I told you what happened with- Doctor: Okay. Okay.

Patient: Yeah, yeah. Doctor: Wow! Small world. Maybe my husband was in training in radiation oncology. Maybe you know him. Family Member: I think so. Doctor: Yeah because (laughs) Patient: Yeah, Yeah. Doctor: You know that was twenty some years ago so that’s probably about right. Family Member: That is. Patient: Yep. Doctor: Okay, alright, so let me check with D__ if your PSA came back. Patient: Okay. Doctor: We are going to do one last ditch effort. I don’t know what’s taking so long even for the labs today. Patient: Oh is that right? Doctor: Yeah.

Patient: Uh hum, okay. Doctor: So if the placebo is a non-starter for you, then we skipped that as an option. But again just thinking broad terms first before we get into those details. Just thinking in broad terms so push off the for hormone therapy for a while and do a targeted radiotherapy instead. Or whether you feel that you just want to go ahead and give the hormone therapy to increase the chances of that lasting as long as possible or do some remission that lasts Patient: And yeah, but the way I’m going, I’d be the one in three. (laughs) Doctor: Okay. Patient: If I had it the other way I would have won the lottery. Doctor: I hear you. I hear you. Patient: So thank you very much. Healthcare Professional: So uhm, how are you feeling? You got a lot of side effects from this. Patient: Well, uhm, with me as far as the medication I was on the worst part of it was I think the joints at first, but then it became progressively better. Healthcare Professional: Okay. Patient: To where once you know I guess I was on the medication long enough, that totally disappeared. But it for a while there it was just crazy. Healthcare Professional: You still have it. Right. Do you still feel it at all or?

Family Member 1: You do nothing. Family Member: You do nothing. They’ll call you. Patient: Oh, you’ll call me? Doctor: I’m not going to call you. The pharmacy will call you. Patient: The pharmacy, right. Family Member: Pharmacy. Right. Patient: And if I don’t hear nothing, then how long, should I call you? Doctor: Give me a week. Just you know, if you use MyChart, you can give us a call. I’ll just follow up with them. They’re usually pretty good about it. Patient: Okay. Family Member: Okay. That’s it. Doctor: Other question you guys have? Patient: Do you want me to leave so you can talk?

Family Member: Okay. Doctor: You can’t actually see the lymph nodes when you remove them, you just see packets of fat. Family Member: Oh. Doctor: Just lumps of fat and the lymph nodes are imbedded in the fat and the pathologist has to find them. Family Member: Oh gosh. Okay. Doctor: So we always go to the same area so we remove these packets of fat from that area along the pelvic side wall, it’s along the iliac arteries. Family Member: Mm, hmm. (pause) Doctor: Yes. Family Member: Okay. And uh oh one more question. Doctor: Um hum. Family Member: Now with these injections, G____ said he won’t be able to have an erection or any of that. Is that even with like using you talk about using Viagra or something else before, even with that you can’t? Doctor: Uh well you could try. There’s no harm in trying. Uh sometimes they depress your drive, your libido, you desire, and so most men just don’t care that much. There’s some men who do care but no matter what you do you can’t knock their drive down. Doctor: And if that’s the case, you can, you can do injection treatments. Did he mention that?

Family Member: In other words, when he eats it’s not going to be as wonderful. Doctor: Yeah. Family Member: One of the things you enjoy. Doctor: But you know, if that's bad and we stop it and quality of life's terrible anymore Family Member: Well, with this neuropathy would this be something that would prevent him from being on this trial. Doctor: Well, you know, it’s yes, in the sense- Family Member: He definitely has it? Doctor: Right. If it's bad enough where you can't button, your shirt or you're constantly dropping things- Patient: Mhmm. Doctor: -or you're burning yourself or you're tripping all the time, that- Patient: My neuropathy is xxx. Doctor: Yeah. Okay. And you know, are you are you falling? Patient: No.

Patient: No. I’m good with the morphine. Doctor: Okay. And you’ve been emailing me? Who’s been writing the pain people? Who’s been doing that for you? Patient: What? Doctor: When you need a refill. Patient: Huh, I call R___. Doctor: Okay. But then they need a doctor to sign it. Patient: Yeah. Hum, that, but I call R___ about, huh, that. Oh. I don’t know. That , it ran out. They sent it seven days too early, and there’s no refills. That’s what I’m saying about, starting seven days early, but I still need them, and I need Doctor: That kind of stuff I can help you with uh if you need a refill, um. Patient: Okay. When I take the ibuprofen, then I might only have to take one of the morphine. You know what I’m saying? More during the day, if the pain coming back just take the ibuprofen and I won’t need morphine. (Coughs) Doctor: So I have a known history, and your hepatitis C, they treated it. Right? Patient: No. It’s in, not, huh, you know how you, huh, you go get this medicine for it? They say I’m not in that category to get anything for it. Doctor: Okay. So your, your hepatitis C isn’t serious and hasn’t, huh, caused any-? Patient: Right.

Family Member: No. He did not. Hum. Doctor: Okay. So did you explain anything to her? Patient: No. She tell me- Family Member: No. But, yes, this is why, right. Yes. This is why I’m here. Doctor: Ah. Okay. Family Member: Because I can’t get a good understanding. Doctor: Okay. Okay. We know the baseline stuff – Family Member: Right. Doctor: - that he has. Family Member: Exactly. Doctor: That’s basically still there. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: But because the PSA was doing a little bit of this creep up-

Patient: And that’s going to be in me for six months. Doctor: Yeah, like they give it to you - it’s like one minute, and you’re done for the month. Family Member: Does he have to keep that catheter in there for the whole month? Doctor: No. Family Member: Oh good. Doctor: Like you put it in (makes mimicking sound) Family Member: So you wouldn’t suggest that he does a lot of walking. Doctor: At this moment, I wouldn’t; I’d just chill out. Time to just kick back. You’ve moved in; don’t do anything else. Patient: We’ve got a lot of Christmas shopping to do. Family Member: I can do the Christmas shopping. Doctor: Why don’t you get on the scooter thing? Family Member: No, he ain’t gonna do that. Doctor: Oh my gosh!
